docs.lead_paragraph: On a recent Friday, 13-year-old Tyshon Young and a nutritionist strolled the aisles at Fairway in Harlem for a little comparison shopping. He picked up a box of butter cookies. She pointed to graham crackers. He picked out Frosted Flakes. She said Special K was a better choice. He picked ice cream. She told him to get the low-fat brand. He wanted a mango. She said he could only have half of one, once or twice a week.

headline.main: With Obesity in Children Rising, More Get Adult Type of Diabetes

docs.abstract: Several small case studies find increasing incidence of Type 2 or adult-onset diabetes in children which doctors previously believed occurred mostly during middle age or later; researchers cite spiraling rate of childhood obesity in America as most significant factor; speculate rise results from both increased incidence of disease and increased awareness of it by primary-care physicians; National Health and Nutrition Examination Surveys find number of obese children has doubled in last two decades; one in five children in America is overweight, with poor minority children who often eat large amounts of junk food and have few neighborhood recreation programs at greatest risk; children affected by disease are mostly African-American and Hispanic, with particularly high rate among children of Mexican descent; most have close relatives with disease and almost all are obese; photo (M)

docs.section_name: Front Page; Health; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: After having an abortion to placate her parents, but not telling them, a Jersey City teen-ager tried to steal infants from two women because her parents said they had changed their minds and welcomed the pregnancy, the police said yesterday.

headline.main: Teen-Ager Is Charged In Kidnapping Attempts

docs.abstract: Jersey City police say 17-year-old girl, after having abortion to placate her parents, tried to steal infants from two woman because her parents changed their minds and welcomed pregnancy (S)
docs.snippet: After having an abortion to placate her parents, but not telling them, a Jersey City teen-ager tried to steal infants from two women because her parents said they had changed their minds and welcomed the pregnancy, the police said yesterday.

docs.lead_paragraph: DURING the long months of my first pregnancy, I exhibited the usual range of tender maternal feelings. As I lay awake at night, I hoped that my daughter would be born healthy, with my husband's hair and with a strong aversion to dating boys who rode motorcycles. But when I went into labor, I forgot such trivial concerns. Between contractions, I was seized by a bizarre, urgent thought: I needed to find my hardcover copy of ''Emma,'' by Jane Austen.

headline.main: I'll Always Love You, but Is It Time to Move On?

docs.abstract: Michelle Slatalla column on her sentimental attachment to her Apple Powerbook 160, which she bought in 1992 and which is seriously outdated now (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A Federal judge today struck down a New Jersey law banning what abortion opponents call partial-birth abortion, saying that the measure was unconstitutional because it would threaten the health of women by denying them access to the safest medical procedures. In issuing a permanent injunction against the law, which legislators passed in 1997 over the veto of Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, the judge ruled that the measure was so vaguely worded that it would ban some of the most common abortion procedures at any point during a pregnancy and failed to make exceptions for cases in which the health or life of the mother was at risk.

headline.main: Ban on Type of Abortion Is Struck Down

docs.abstract: Federal District Court Judge Anne E Thompson strikes down New Jersey law banning what abortion opponents call partial-birth abortion, saying that measure is unconstitutional because it would threaten health of women by denying them access to safest medical procedures; rules that measure is so vaguely worded that it would ban some of most common abortion procedures at any point during pregnancy and fails to make exceptions for cases in which health or life of mother is at risk (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Americans' life span grew to a record high last year, the nation's infant mortality rate fell to a new low, and births in the United States outnumbered deaths by about the same as in 1996, a report issued today said. Life expectancy in the United States reached 76.5 years in 1997, and the nation's infant mortality rate fell to a record low of 7.1 deaths per 1,000 live births, the summary report from Johns Hopkins University and the National Center for Health Statistics said.

headline.main: National News Briefs; Americans' Life Span Rises to Record High

docs.abstract: Report by Johns Hopkins University and National Center for Health Statistics finds Americans' life span grew to record high in 1997, that infant mortality rate fell to new low, and births in outnumbered deaths by about same as in 1996; life expectancy was 76.1 years, infant mortality was 7.2 deaths per 1,000 live births; births outnumbered deaths by 1.6 million (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: A State Supreme Court jury in Queens awarded $26 million yesterday to a family whose child was severely brain damaged during delivery at a city hospital 10 years ago. The jury determined that senior doctors at Elmhurst Hospital had failed to properly oversee the birth of Tina Patel in November 1988, the Patel family's lawyer, Steven E. Pegalis, said. Although the infant had been in a breech position, resident doctors decided to attempt a vaginal birth.

headline.main: $26 Million Is Awarded In Handling of a Birth

docs.abstract: New York State Supreme Court jury in Queens awards $26 million to family of Tina Patel, child who was severely brain damaged during delivery at Elmhurst Hospital ten years ago (S)
